Shell Basics.quote: #!/bin/bash - The shebang line tells the system this is a bash script.

File Operations.quote: ls, cp, mv, rm - The fundamental commands for listing, copying, moving, and removing files.

Directory Management.quote: mkdir creates directories, cd changes directories, pwd prints working directory, rmdir removes empty directories.

Text Processing.quote: grep searches text, sed streams editor, awk pattern scanning and processing language.

Process Control.quote: ps shows processes, kill terminates processes, top displays system activity.

File Permissions.quote: chmod changes mode, chown changes owner, chgrp changes group.

Input/Output.quote: echo prints text, read gets user input, cat concatenates files, > redirects output, >> appends output.

Variables.quote: NAME='value' assigns variables, $NAME or ${NAME} references variables.

Environment Variables.quote: $PATH, $HOME, $USER - System-wide variables that control bash behavior.

Conditionals.quote: if [ condition ]; then commands; fi - Tests conditions and executes based on results.

Loops.quote: for, while, until - Different ways to repeat commands based on conditions.

Functions.quote: function_name() { commands; } - Reusable blocks of code.

Command Substitution.quote: result=$(command) or result=`command` - Captures command output in variables.

Pipeline.quote: command1 | command2 - Sends output of command1 as input to command2.

Shell Options.quote: set -e exits on error, set -x prints commands as they execute.

Error Handling.quote: trap 'commands' EXIT/ERR - Catches and handles script errors.

Debugging.quote: bash -x script.sh, set -x - Traces script execution for debugging.

Job Control.quote: bg puts jobs in background, fg brings to foreground, jobs lists active jobs.

File Testing.quote: -e tests existence, -f tests regular file, -d tests directory.

Arithmetic.quote: $((expression)), let "a = b + c" - Performs mathematical calculations.

Signal Handling.quote: trap catches signals, kill sends signals to processes.

Shell History.quote: history shows command history, !n repeats nth command.

Path Manipulation.quote: basename strips directory, dirname keeps only directory.

File Descriptors.quote: 0 is stdin, 1 is stdout, 2 is stderr - Standard I/O streams.

Shell Scripting.quote: Scripts combine commands for automation and complex tasks.

Command Line Arguments.quote: $0 is script name, $1-$9 are arguments, $# is argument count.

Exit Status.quote: $? contains exit status of last command, 0 means success.
